results.title: Keeping ourselves safe
results.brief_description: Seven short dramatized vignettes on the subject of adults and older youths attempting to make sexual advances to children: “Fathers friend”, “The Photos”, “The Baby sitter”, “Jane and her uncle”, “The Swimming baths”, “Amanda and her father” and “On the bus”.

results.title: Keeping electricity safe outside the home
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Sydney County Council and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Advance Australia”.
A film made to show children the way to avoid the dangers of electic light wires out-of-doors. A linesman explains to children why it is dangerous to touch electric light wires and advises what to do if a broken wire is found. Shows how wires may be broken by kites and footballs. Warns of the danger of contact with wires touching trees and of contact with wires on the roof of a house.

results.title: Keeping electricity safe inside the home
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Sydney County Council, Jean Halliday and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: Informative study of all the checks that should be made on day to day use of electrical equipment in the home (irons, toasters etc) and precautions to be taken with a general knowledge of electrical operation and illustrated details.

results.title: Keeping animals in the classroom
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal, Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Education for Zoo Education Service and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Trevor Lunn introduces Karen Svalesen from the Zoo Education Service who examines the problems that can be encountered when keeping animals in the classroom. Suggests suitable animals and information sources to assist with animal care.

results.title: Keepin' silent
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This compilation of footage from Australia’s silent era (1896-1930) encompasses examples of actuality, documentary, newsreels, home movies, advertisements, animation, narrative shorts and features. With piano accompaniment by Mrs Betty Magner.

results.title: Keepers of wildlife
results.creator_credit: George Pearson, ONF | NFB and Michael McKennirey
results.brief_description: Canada’s wilderness areas harbor some of the last remaining species of North American wildlife. This film shows what is being done by specialists of the Canadian Wildlife Service to prevent further depletion of their numbers. It is an enormous program of tabulating, banding, tagging, and, in the case of larger animals such as the bear and the buffalo, giving health check-ups. An engrossing film for any audience, replete with close-ups of animals, waterfowl, and fish.

results.title: Keepers of the mystery
results.brief_description: A Poetic travellogue of Scotland, documenting the distillation process of whisky on an industrial level, including barrel construction, blending, tasting (malt whisky and grain whiskey), Packaging and distribution. The film ends with a charming animated commercial for Whitehorse Cellar Scotch Whisky.

results.title: Keepers of the fire
results.creator_credit: Nola Wuttunee, Brenda Hennig, Andy Thomson and Great North Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “From spirit to spirit (A)”.
This program focuses on the work of four Elders from a North American Indian tribe in Canada, who were survivors of the prison system. After leaving the reserves, it is not uncommon for those who had made the move to the city, to become caught in a vicious cycle within the criminal justice system. The Elders attempt to work with young offenders using their own experiences and knowledge of the traditional way of life, to educate the young people into developing a sense of self worth and hopefully prevent them from becoming caught in a similar cycle.

results.title: Keep the river on your right [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Next Wave Films, Lifer Films, David Shapiro and Laurie Shapiro
results.brief_description: Keep the river on your right is a fascinating documentary about anthropologist Tobias Schneebaum, a New York native who in the year 1955 (aged 34) travelled to Peru to study the tribes people there. Schneebaum’s experiences garnered him notoriety upon his return - he lived with the tribes and even partook in a cannibalistic raid on another village. This documentary tracks Schneebaum’s visit to that same village 45 years later, displaying his ambivalence about returning there. Archival footage of Schneebaum appearing on numerous chat shows does much to display the cultural imperialism of American attitudes as well as Schneebaum’s own sensitive views towards those he studied. Schneebaum, an author and artist of some repute is also shown lecturing on the Asmat tribe of Papua New Guinea, who openly embrace bisexuality as a way of life. On a study tour there, Schneebaum (who is gay) had a lover, with whom as a much older man he is reunited. This documentary has some scenes, including a male circumcision, which may disturb some viewers.
